channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Letter From Washington: Distortions That Still Require Decisive Action
item.description: On none of the current so-called scandals in Washington is there any suggestion of wrongdoing by President Barack Obama. But there are bold actions Mr. Obama could consider.
item.dc:creator: By ALBERT R. HUNT | BLOOMBERG VIEW

item.title: Syrian Troops Said to Strike Town Near Lebanon
item.description: The Syrian military on Sunday launched an offensive to retake a strategic rebel-held town near the Lebanese border, a government official said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Joseph Farman, 82, Is Dead; Discovered Ozone Hole
item.description: Mr. Farman’s single-minded and at times officially derided study of atmospheric changes in the Antarctic led to one of the most important environmental discoveries of the 20th century.
item.dc:creator: By PAUL VITELLO

item.title: Kenneth N. Waltz, Who Helped Shape International Relations as a Discipline, Dies at 88
item.description: Mr. Waltz, who was a senior research scholar at Columbia, was a pre-eminent thinker who was known for his contrarian, debate-provoking ideas.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

item.title: In a Journey on a Crumbling Railway, a Picture of a Nation’s Troubles
item.description: A journey across Pakistan’s crumbling railway presents a picture of the country’s troubles: natural disasters and hardened insurgencies, abject poverty and feudal kleptocrats, and an economy near meltdown.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH
item.media:credit: Andrea Bruce for The New York Times
item.media:description: Trying to fix the tracks near Lahore. Pakistan’s railways, which once linked a fractious young nation, have been neglected.

item.title: Exposés of China’s Elite a Big Lure in Hong Kong
item.description: Visitors from mainland China turn to Hong Kong bookstores for forbidden delights: shelves of scandal-packed exposés about their Communist Party masters.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: The People’s Recreation Community bookstore in Hong Kong, which carries scandalous books about Communist leaders.

item.title: Maze Prison’s Future Stirs Up Ghosts of Its Past
item.description: With a peace center planned for Maze prison, home of an I.R.A. hunger strike, some in Northern Ireland are revisiting the complex story of the Troubles.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS DALBY
item.media:description: Maze prison in 1979 in Northern Ireland. A center for the study of peace and conflict resolution is planned for the site.

item.title: Gunmen Kill Pakistan Party Official
item.description: Police said Zohra Shahid, the vice president of Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf, was killed by gunmen on a motorcycle outside her home in Karachi in southern Sindh Province.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Anwar, Malaysia’s Opposition Leader, Takes to the Streets
item.description: Anwar Ibrahim has returned to his roots as a political street fighter, drawing large crowds across the country to protest what he calls mass vote rigging.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:credit: Sanjit Das for the International Herald Tribune
item.media:description: Anwar Ibrahim, the Malaysian opposition leader, on Tuesday at his office outside Kuala Lumpur. The election was held May 5.

item.title: The Health Toll of Immigration
item.description: A growing body of mortality research on immigrants has shown that the longer they live in the United States, the worse their rates of heart disease, high blood pressure and diabetes.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: By SABRINA TAVERNISE
item.media:credit: J. Michael Short for The New York Times
item.media:description: Esther Angeles, 41, with her daughter, Johanna Marisol Gomez, 7. Ms. Angeles has developed diabetes since coming to the United States and struggles to see that her daughter eats healthfully.

item.title: Police Officers Are Targets in Wave of Afghan Violence
item.description: Nearly two dozen Afghan police officers and civilians have been killed in the last few days, including a district police official assassinated over a recent anti-Taliban campaign.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED

item.title: Pakistan, as Seen Through its Railways
item.description: At every major stop on the long line from Peshawar to the turbulent port city of Karachi lie reminders of why the country is a worry to its people, and to the wider world.

item.title: The Lede: Long Before Crack Cocaine Allegations, Toronto Mayor Was a Source of Controversy
item.description: Questions have been raised about Mayor Rob Ford’s conduct, temperament and public statements since his early days as a member of the Toronto City Council.
item.dc:creator: By JENNIFER PRESTON and LIAM STACK

item.title: Strategies: Japan Starts to Recharge After Two Lost Economic Decades
item.description: It’s hard to tell if Japan’s new experiments in economic policy will work in the long run, but they have already caused world markets to take notice.
item.dc:creator: By JEFF SOMMER
item.media:credit: Jiji Press, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Shinzo Abe, Japan’s prime minister, taking a spin on a rice planter. His economic plan has cheered investors.

item.title: Syria’s Assad Says Peace Talks Likely to Fail
item.description: President Bashar al-Assad backed away from earlier statements by Syrian officials that the government was willing to negotiate with its armed opponents.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Buildings damaged this month in Raqqa Province after what rebels said was shelling by Syrian government forces.

item.title: Efforts to Strengthen Afghan Law on Women May Backfire
item.description: Amending a law that holds families accountable for the mistreatment of women risks losing minimal protections.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: The scene in a Kabul store selling burqas, a garment that has come to exemplify the many limitations women in Afghanistan face.

item.title: Climber Is First Saudi Woman to Scale Mount Everest
item.description: A climber became the first Saudi woman to climb Mount Everest when she reached the peak successfully with 63 others, according to mountaineering officials.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Under Pressure, China Measures Its Impact in Myanmar
item.description: Grass-roots protests against Chinese oil projects are worrying Beijing as it competes for influence in Myanmar with the United States.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ and BREE FENG
item.media:credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Villagers in Se Tae, Myanmar, spoke against a project by China’s Wanbao Mining Corporation at the base of Letpadaung mountain.

item.title: South Korea Says North Launches 3 Missiles Into Sea
item.description: The tests broke the recent relative silence from the North, but the move was much less provocative than what had been feared earlier this year.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Hollande Signs French Gay Marriage Law
item.description: For President François Hollande, passage of the law despite public opposition was a significant victory given his campaign promise to legalize gay marriage within the first year of his administration.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Americas Coalition Puts Marijuana Legalization Up for Discussion
item.description: A report released by the Organization of American States encouraged “flexibility” in how the drug war is carried out, including considering the legalization of marijuana.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

item.title: India Ink: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
item.description: A round-up of news from across India.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: France's Hollande Signs Gay Marriage Law
item.description: French President Francois Hollande has signed into law a bill allowing same-sex marriage, making France the 14th country to legalize gay weddings.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Arts | Long Island: Review of Exhibition on Jews in Greece During the Holocaust in Glen Cove
item.description: An exhibition about the history of the hard-hit community of Greek Sephardic Jews is at the Tolerance Center in Glen Cove, N.Y.
item.category: Holocaust Memorial and Tolerance Center of Nassau County
item.dc:creator: By AILEEN JACOBSON
item.media:credit: Kathy Kmonicek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Northport Middle School students at the exhibition in Glen Cove

item.title: Congress Answers Obama Plan With Smaller Food Aid Changes
item.description: After the Obama administration proposed moving the international food aid program out of the Agriculture Department, the Congressional Agriculture Committees took lesser actions.
item.dc:creator: By RON NIXON
